unnormalised: Someone asked me about the best way to donate to charity in India, and I thought I’d share my thoughts here. It's a great question, and important to be thoughtful about where your ₹ goes. There are so many organisations asking for funds, it's hard to choose!
normalised: Someone asked me about the best way to donate to charity in India, and I thought I’d share my thoughts here. It's a great question, and important to be thoughtful about where your rupee goes. There are so many organizations asking for funds, it's hard to choose!

unnormalised: Firstly, consider what cause you're passionate about. Want to help children get educated? Maybe something environment-related? There are NGOs working in all sorts of areas. Do some research online – websites like GiveIndia or Charities Aid Foundation (CAF) list lots of verified charities. Check their 80G status for tax benefits, that way you can claim deductions later! Plus, double check the FCRA status if they receive foreign funds, just for your peace of mind.
normalised: Firstly, consider what cause you're passionate about. Want to help children get educated? Maybe something environment related? There are N-G-Os working in all sorts of areas. Do some research online – websites like GiveIndia or Charities Aid Foundation (C-A-F) list lots of verified charities. Check their eighty G status for tax benefits, that way you can claim deductions later! Plus, double check the F-C-R-A status if they receive foreign funds, just for your peace of mind.

unnormalised: When you've found a charity you like, look into how they use the money. A good charity will be transparent about its finances. See if they publish an annual report – that’s usually a good sign. Don’t just go by emotional appeals. Look for data and real impact! You can often donate online via credit card, UPI, or net banking. Some might even accept donations via Paytm or Google Pay. Amounts can vary; some accept as little as Rs. 100 while others have minimum donation amounts like Rs. 500.

See if they publish an annual report – that’s usually a good sign. Don’t just go by emotional appeals. Look for data and real impact! You can often donate online via credit card, U-P-I, or net banking. Some might even accept donations via P-a-y-T-m or Google Pay. Amounts can vary; some accept as little as rupees one hundred while others have minimum donation amounts like rupees five hundred.

unnormalised: Remember, even small amounts make a difference! Donating Rs. 200-300 a month adds up over time. Also, think about donating in kind. You could donate old clothes, books, or even your time! Many organisations need volunteers. And don’t feel pressured to give more than you can afford. Every bit counts.
normalised: Remember, even small amounts make a difference! Donating rupees two hundred to three hundred a month adds up over time. Also, think about donating in kind. You could donate old clothes, books, or even your time! Many organizations need volunteers. And don’t feel pressured to give more than you can afford. Every bit counts.

unnormalised: Finally, be wary of unsolicited requests, especially online. Phishing is real, so always double-check the website before entering your bank details. Look for the secure padlock icon in your browser! And trust your gut. If something feels off, it probably is. Happy donating!
